text:
I just upgraded from Apache/2.0.39 (Win32) PHP/4.2.2  to Apache/2.0.40 (Win32)
so that I could get a htpasswd that works, but now running a test on the config 
file fails on the line:

LoadModule php4_module c:/php/php4apache2.dll

with a complaint about "procedure not found".

I thought it was a path resolution issue, but it isn't.  I now suspect there 
are changed parameter/entry point requirements for external modules in 2.0.40 - 
I'm using the standard binary distributions under Windows XP and don't have a 
compiler so can't delve deeper.

Reverting to 2.0.39 resolves the issue.

I bet this is an PHP issue. You might look in the PHP bug database and report the bug there if 
applicable. (btw, same problem on Windows 2000 Pro too)
creator: psychosos@gmx.at

text:
Each version of Apache potentially breaks existing modules.

  See your 3rd party module vendor for an update built for Apache 2.0.40.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
> Each version of Apache potentially breaks existing modules.
> See your 3rd party module vendor for an update built for Apache 2.0.40.

While I accept that you've closed this bug, it's not good software engineering 
for such minor patches to change the interfacing used by external modules 
without warning - usually such changes are reserved for more substantial 
releases and users warned that existing module extensions won't work.
creator: mcrooks88@hotmail.com

text:
The difference between Apache and other servers is the level of modularity.

  Most servers have a limited subset of supported, externally accessable
  functionality.  Apache, OTOH, gives any module a transparent window into
  the ENTIRE server, the code, data structures etc.  This is what makes Apache
  server modules so powerful and flexible.  It is also what forces us to break
  module compatibility over the smallest details when they change.

  Other web servers change no more or less than Apache from version to version,
  and service pack to service pack.  They simply hide ALL those details from the
  module, so that the external modules are unaffected by internal changes.

  The Apache project works hard to keep these sorts of changes to a minimum, but
  there is often no alternative.  That's why all 1.3.14 through 1.3.2x servers
  were compatible with one another, but 1.3.12 and 1.3.14 were not.
